  11. 额外指标:特异性、活性、稳定性
  12. 迭代优化:基于计算预测的性质进行迭代改进

docs.title: 二、实验验证阶段
docs.text:
1. 抗体基因合成与表达

  2. 基因合成

    • 优化密码子使用
    • 合成重链和轻链基因
    • 克隆至适当表达载体

  3. 表达系统选择

    • 哺乳动物细胞系(HEK293, CHO)
    • 杆状病毒-昆虫细胞系统
    • 酵母或大肠杆菌系统(适用于抗体片段)

  4. 小规模表达筛选

    • 瞬时转染优化
    • 表达条件筛选(温度、添加剂、培养时间)
    • ELISA或Western blot初步验证表达

  5. 抗体蛋白纯化与质控

  6. 亲和层析纯化

    • 蛋白A/G柱纯化(适用于Fc含抗体)
    • 抗原亲和柱(针对特定抗体)
    • 标签亲和纯化(His标签、FLAG标签等)

  7. 进一步纯化

    • 离子交换层析
    • 分子筛层析
    • 疏水相互作用层析

  8. 质量控制分析

    • SDS-PAGE和考马斯蓝染色
    • 质谱分析确认序列和修饰
    • 凝胶过滤分析评估聚集状态
    • 内毒素检测

  9. 生物物理特性分析

  10. 结构完整性验证

    • 圆二色谱(CD)分析二级结构
    • 差示扫描量热法(DSC)测定热稳定性
    • 动态光散射(DLS)评估均一性和聚集倾向

  11. 稳定性测试

    • 加速稳定性研究(高温、pH变化)
    • 冻融循环稳定性
    • 长期储存稳定性

  12. 亲和力测定

    • 表面等离子体共振(SPR)测量结合动力学参数
    • 等温滴定量热法(ITC)测量热力学参数
    • Bio-layer干涉法(BLI)快速筛选

  13. 功能活性验证

  14. 抗原结合特性

    • ELISA测定结合活性
    • 竞争结合实验评估表位特异性
    • 交叉反应性测试(与相关抗原或其他物种同源物)

  15. 细胞水平功能验证

    • 流式细胞术评估细胞表面抗原结合
    • 免疫荧光显微镜观察细胞定位
    • 细胞功能测定(如中和、抑制、激活等)

  16. 效应功能测试

    • 抗体依赖性细胞介导的细胞毒性(ADCC)测定
    • 补体依赖性细胞毒性(CDC)测定
    • 抗体依赖性细胞吞噬作用(ADCP)测定

  17. 体外疗效评估

  18. 信号通路分析

    • Western blot检测下游信号蛋白磷酸化
    • 荧光素酶报告基因测定
    • 磷酸化蛋白组学分析

  19. 功能性测定

    • 细胞增殖/凋亡测定
    • 细胞迁移/侵袭测定
    • 细胞分化测定
    • 病毒中和测定(用于抗病毒抗体)

  20. 三维模型系统

    • 类器官培养系统
    • 细胞球测试
    • 共培养系统

  21. 体内初步评估

  22. 药代动力学研究

    • 小鼠、大鼠或非人灵长类动物中的半衰期测定
    • 组织分布研究
    • 清除机制研究

  23. 初步疗效研究

    • 选择适当疾病模型(移植瘤、转基因或疾病诱导模型)
    • 剂量探索研究
    • 生物标志物响应评估

  24. 初步安全性评估

    • 急性毒性观察
    • 细胞因子释放测试
    • 组织交叉反应性研究

  25. 抗体优化反馈

  26. 结构-功能关系分析

    • 将实验数据与计算预测对比
    • 识别影响功能的关键残基
    • 归纳结构决定因素

  27. 设计改进

    • 基于实验数据修改计算模型
    • 设计新一代抗体改进特定性能
    • 亲和力成熟或人源化优化

  28. 制剂开发初步研究

    • 缓冲液筛选
    • 稳定剂评估
    • 冻干可行性研究

这一综合流程将计算设计与严格的实验验证相结合，确保开发的抗体不仅具有理想的理论特性，还具备实际的功能活性和药物开发潜力。通过实验数据反馈到计算模型，可以不断优化设计算法，提高预测准确性，加速抗体药物的开发过程。

docs.title: Antibody Design Pipeline: From Computational Design to Experimental Validation
I. Computational Design Phase
docs.text:
1. Initial Inputs
  2. Antigen structure (crystal structure or computational prediction)
  3. Epitope identification and selection

  4. Analysis of existing antibody databases

  5. Design Approaches

  6. De novo design: Build main chain → complete side chains → generate sequence
  7. Mutation-based optimization: Systematic exploration of mutations within constrained search space

  8. Structure prediction tools: AlphaFold2, ESM-Fold, AF3, DMFold for validation/prediction

  9. Developability Assessment

  10. MPGNN, RF Diffusion (DDPM), SCUBA-D for affinity computation
  11. Additional metrics: specificity, activity, stability
  12. Optimization loop: Iterative refinement based on computationally predicted properties

docs.title: II. Experimental Validation Phase
docs.text:
1. Antibody Gene Synthesis and Expression

  2. Gene Synthesis

    • Codon optimization
    • Synthesis of heavy and light chain genes
    • Cloning into appropriate expression vectors

  3. Expression System Selection

    • Mammalian cell lines (HEK293, CHO)
    • Baculovirus-insect cell system
    • Yeast or E. coli systems (for antibody fragments)

  4. Small-Scale Expression Screening

    • Transient transfection optimization
    • Expression condition screening (temperature, additives, culture time)
    • Preliminary validation by ELISA or Western blot

  5. Antibody Protein Purification and Quality Control

  6. Affinity Chromatography

    • Protein A/G column purification (for Fc-containing antibodies)

    • Tag-based purification (His-tag, FLAG-tag, etc.)

  7. Further Purification

    • Ion exchange chromatography

    • Hydrophobic interaction chromatography

  8. Quality Control Analysis

    • SDS-PAGE and Coomassie blue staining

    • Gel filtration analysis for aggregation assessment
    • Endotoxin testing

  9. Biophysical Characterization

  10. Structural Integrity Verification

    • Circular dichroism (CD) for secondary structure analysis
    • Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) for thermal stability
    • Dynamic light scattering (DLS) for homogeneity and aggregation propensity

  11. Stability Testing

    • Accelerated stability studies (high temperature, pH variations)
    • Freeze-thaw cycle stability
    • Long-term storage stability

  12. Affinity Determination

    • Surface plasmon resonance (SPR) for binding kinetics parameters
    • Isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC) for thermodynamic parameters
    • Bio-layer interferometry (BLI) for rapid screening

  13. Functional Activity Validation

  14. Antigen Binding Characteristics

    • ELISA for binding activity
    • Competition binding assays for epitope specificity
    • Cross-reactivity testing (with related antigens or homologs from other species)

  15. Cellular-Level Functional Validation

    • Flow cytometry for cell surface antigen binding
    • Immunofluorescence microscopy for cellular localization
    • Cell-based functional assays (neutralization, inhibition, activation, etc.)

  16. Effector Function Testing

    • Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) assays
    • Complement-dependent cytotoxicity (CDC) assays
    • Antibody-dependent cellular phagocytosis (ADCP) assays

  17. In Vitro Efficacy Assessment

  18. Signaling Pathway Analysis

    • Western blot for downstream signaling protein phosphorylation
    • Luciferase reporter assays
    • Phospho-proteomics analysis

  19. Functional Assays

    • Cell proliferation/apoptosis assays
    • Cell migration/invasion assays
    • Cell differentiation assays
    • Viral neutralization assays (for antiviral antibodies)

  20. Three-Dimensional Model Systems

    • Organoid culture systems
    • Spheroid assays
    • Co-culture systems

  21. Preliminary In Vivo Evaluation

  22. Pharmacokinetic Studies

    • Half-life determination in mice, rats, or non-human primates
    • Tissue distribution studies
    • Clearance mechanism studies

  23. Preliminary Efficacy Studies

    • Selection of appropriate disease models (xenografts, transgenic, or disease-induced models)
    • Dose exploration studies
    • Biomarker response assessment

  24. Preliminary Safety Assessment

    • Acute toxicity observations
    • Cytokine release assays
    • Tissue cross-reactivity studies

  25. Antibody Optimization Feedback

  26. Structure-Function Relationship Analysis

    • Comparison of experimental data with computational predictions
    • Identification of key residues affecting function
    • Deduction of structural determinants

  27. Design Improvements

    • Modification of computational models based on experimental data
    • Design of next-generation antibodies with improved specific properties
    • Affinity maturation or humanization optimization

  28. Preliminary Formulation Development

    • Buffer screening
    • Stabilizer evaluation
    • Lyophilization feasibility studies

This comprehensive pipeline integrates computational design with rigorous experimental validation, ensuring that developed antibodies not only possess ideal theoretical characteristics but also demonstrate practical functional activity and drug development potential. By feeding experimental data back into computational models, design algorithms can be continuously optimized, improving prediction accuracy and accelerating the antibody drug development process.

docs.title: Kaplan-Meier估计与Log-rank检验的数学原理与应用
1. 基本原理
docs.text:
Kaplan-Meier估计器是一种非参数方法，用于估计存在右审查数据时的生存函数。其核心思想是将生存概率表示为一系列条件概率的乘积。

生存函数S(t)的定义为在时间t之后仍未发生事件的概率：

S(t) = P(T > t)

其中T是事件发生的时间。

docs.title: 2. 数学推导
docs.text:
假设我们有观察到的事件发生时间t₁ < t₂ < ... < tₖ，Kaplan-Meier估计器通过以下步骤构建：

  1. 条件概率分解： 生存函数可以表示为连续条件概率的乘积： S(t) = P(T > t₁) × P(T > t₂|T > t₁) × ... × P(T > t|T > tⱼ) 其中tⱼ是小于t的最大观察时间点。

  2. 条件概率估计： 在每个时间点tᵢ，我们估计条件概率： P(T > tᵢ|T > tᵢ₋₁) = 1 - dᵢ/nᵢ 其中：

  3. dᵢ = 在时间tᵢ发生事件的数量

  4. nᵢ = 在时间tᵢ处于"风险集"中的对象数量（即在tᵢ之前既没有发生事件也没有被审查的对象）

  5. 乘积极限估计器： Kaplan-Meier估计器的最终形式为： Ŝ(t) = ∏ₖ:ₜₖ≤ₜ (1 - dₖ/nₖ) 这是一个阶梯函数，在每个事件发生时间点处下降，在审查时间点保持不变。

docs.title: 3. 方差估计与置信区间
docs.text:
Kaplan-Meier估计器的方差通常使用Greenwood公式估计：

Var[Ŝ(t)] = [Ŝ(t)]² × ∑ₖ:ₜₖ≤ₜ [dₖ/(nₖ×(nₖ-dₖ))]

95%置信区间可以通过多种方法构建：

  1. 线性近似： Ŝ(t) ± 1.96 × √Var[Ŝ(t)]

  2. 对数变换（更常用）： Ŝ(t)^exp(±1.96×σ/[Ŝ(t)×log(Ŝ(t))]) 其中σ是Ŝ(t)的标准误。

  3. log-log变换： 基于log(-log(Ŝ(t)))的渐近正态性，提供更好的覆盖概率。

docs.title: 4. 中位生存时间
docs.text:
中位生存时间是使S(t) = 0.5的时间t，即：

tₘₑₐₙ = min{t: Ŝ(t) ≤ 0.5}

当生存曲线未降至0.5以下时，中位生存时间不可估计。

docs.title: 1. 曲线特性
docs.text:
• 阶梯函数：曲线在事件发生时下降，在审查时不变
  • 初始值：S(0) = 1（假设所有对象在研究开始时都未发生事件）
  • 终值：如果最后的观察是事件而非审查，则曲线可能降至0；如果最后的观察是审查，则曲线不会达到0
  • 平台期：曲线中的水平段表示该时间段内未观察到事件
  • 陡降：曲线急剧下降表示事件密集发生

docs.title: 2. 审查标记
docs.text:
Kaplan-Meier曲线上通常用特殊符号（如"+"或短垂线）标记审查点，这些标记提供了关于数据完整性的重要信息：

  • 审查标记的分布表明研究的随访模式
  • 曲线末端大量审查标记提示随访时间可能不足
  • 不同组别审查模式的差异可能暗示潜在偏倚

docs.title: 3. 风险表
docs.text:
Kaplan-Meier图下方通常附有"风险表"(risk table)，显示各时间点仍处于风险中的对象数量：

Time:    0    6    12   18   24   30
At risk: 100  87   75   54   32   15

风险表提供了重要上下文信息： - 显示样本量随时间减少 - 帮助解释曲线末端的不确定性增加 - 在比较多组时尤为重要，表明各时间点的组间样本量平衡情况

docs.title: 1. 基本假设与思想
docs.text:
Log-rank检验是比较两个或多个生存曲线的非参数方法，基于以下假设：

  • 零假设(H₀)：各组的生存函数相同，即S₁(t) = S₂(t) = ... = Sₖ(t)
  • 替代假设(H₁)：至少有一组的生存函数与其他组不同

检验的核心思想是：如果零假设为真，则各组在每个时间点观察到的事件数应与期望事件数接近。

docs.title: 2. 数学构造
docs.text:
考虑在每个观察到事件的时间点tᵢ，构建如下2×2表（以两组比较为例）：

          事件    无事件    风险集
组1        O₁ᵢ    n₁ᵢ-O₁ᵢ    n₁ᵢ
组2        O₂ᵢ    n₂ᵢ-O₂ᵢ    n₂ᵢ
总计       dᵢ      nᵢ-dᵢ     nᵢ

其中： - O₁ᵢ, O₂ᵢ = 各组在时间tᵢ观察到的事件数 - n₁ᵢ, n₂ᵢ = 各组在时间tᵢ的风险集大小 - dᵢ = 在时间tᵢ发生的总事件数 - nᵢ = 在时间tᵢ的总风险集大小

在零假设下，O₁ᵢ近似服从超几何分布，其期望值为：

E₁ᵢ = n₁ᵢ × (dᵢ/nᵢ)

方差为：

V₁ᵢ = n₁ᵢ × n₂ᵢ × dᵢ × (nᵢ-dᵢ) / [nᵢ² × (nᵢ-1)]

docs.title: 3. 检验统计量构造
docs.text:
Log-rank检验统计量通过汇总所有时间点的观察值与期望值之差：

  1. 对每个组j计算： Oⱼ = ∑ᵢOⱼᵢ （总观察事件数） Eⱼ = ∑ᵢEⱼᵢ （总期望事件数）

  2. 构造检验统计量： 对于两组比较： χ² = (O₁-E₁)² / Var(O₁-E₁) 其中Var(O₁-E₁) = ∑ᵢV₁ᵢ

对于多组比较（k组）： χ² = U'V⁻¹U 其中U是长度为(k-1)的向量，元素为Oⱼ-Eⱼ，V是(k-1)×(k-1)的协方差矩阵。

  1. 分布： 在零假设下，χ²统计量近似服从自由度为(组数-1)的卡方分布。

docs.title: 4. p值解释
docs.text:
Log-rank检验的p值表示在零假设为真的条件下，观察到当前或更极端差异的概率：

  • p < 0.05：通常认为存在统计学显著差异，拒绝零假设
  • p值越小，证据越强烈支持组间生存曲线存在差异
  • p值不能告诉我们差异的大小或临床意义

docs.title: 1. 加权Log-rank检验
docs.text:
标准Log-rank检验对所有时间点赋予相同权重，但在某些情况下，我们可能希望强调特定时间段的差异。加权Log-rank检验通过引入权重函数W(t)实现这一目的：

χ²_w = [∑ᵢW(tᵢ)(O₁ᵢ-E₁ᵢ)]² / ∑ᵢW(tᵢ)²V₁ᵢ

常见的加权版本包括：

  1. Gehan-Breslow-Wilcoxon检验：
  2. 权重W(t) = nᵢ（风险集大小）
  3. 强调早期差异

  4. 当审查模式不同时更稳健

  5. Peto-Peto检验：

  6. 权重W(t) = S̃(t)，其中S̃(t)是修改的Kaplan-Meier估计
  7. 对晚期事件较少依赖

  8. 对不同审查模式更稳健

  9. Fleming-Harrington检验：

  10. 权重W(t) = [Ŝ(t)]ᵖ[1-Ŝ(t)]ᵍ
  11. 参数p,q可调整，强调早期(p>0,q=0)或晚期(p=0,q>0)差异
  12. 灵活性高，适用于特定研究问题

docs.title: 2. 分层Log-rank检验
docs.text:
当存在可能影响生存的混杂因素时，分层Log-rank检验允许在控制这些因素的同时比较主要分组因素的效应：

  1. 方法：
  2. 在每个分层水平内分别计算观察值与期望值

  3. 汇总所有分层的结果

  4. 统计量： χ²_stratified = [∑ₛ∑ᵢ(O₁ᵢₛ-E₁ᵢₛ)]² / ∑ₛ∑ᵢV₁ᵢₛ 其中s表示分层水平。

  5. 应用场景：

  6. 多中心临床试验（按中心分层）
  7. 存在已知预后因素（如疾病分期）时

docs.title: 五、Kaplan-Meier曲线与Log-rank检验的应用考量
1. 样本量与统计检验力
docs.text:
Log-rank检验的检验力取决于： - 事件总数（通常比总样本量更重要） - 预期的效应大小（风险比） - 显著性水平（通常为0.05）

样本量计算公式：

所需事件数 = 4 × (z_α/2 + z_β)² / [log(HR)]²

其中: - z_α/2 = 显著性水平对应的z值（1.96对应α=0.05） - z_β = 检验力对应的z值（0.84对应80%检验力） - HR = 预期风险比

docs.title: 2. 假设验证
docs.text:
Log-rank检验基于以下假设： - 比例风险假设：各组的风险函数之比随时间保持恒定 - 独立审查假设：审查机制与事件发生机制相互独立 - 组间独立性：不同组别的观察相互独立

验证方法： - 绘制log(-log(S(t)))对log(t)的图，检查曲线平行性 - 检查审查模式在各组间的分布 - 评估时间依赖效应

docs.title: 3. 解释陷阱与注意事项
docs.text:
1. 审查处理：
  2. 审查数据不是"缺失数据"，而是包含部分信息

  3. 忽略审查或将审查视为事件都会导致严重偏倚

  4. 交叉生存曲线：

  5. 当生存曲线交叉时，Log-rank检验可能无法检测到差异
  6. 交叉曲线暗示违反比例风险假设

  7. 考虑使用加权Log-rank检验或分段分析

  8. 长尾效应：

  9. 曲线末端基于很少的风险集，估计不确定性大
  10. 末端的看似显著差异可能仅基于几个事件

  11. 关注风险表和置信区间宽度

  12. 多重比较：

  13. 比较多组时需要考虑多重检验校正

  14. 常用方法：Bonferroni校正、Holm方法、Hochberg方法

  15. 临床相关性：

  16. 统计显著性不等同于临床意义
  17. 评估绝对差异（如5年生存率差异）和中位生存时间差异
  18. 考

docs.title: S2W4.3 Host microbial Interactions and Lipid Metabolism
docs.text: 肠道微生物调控宿主脂质代谢的实验工作流程

docs.title: 一、动物模型建立与表征
docs.text:
1. 无菌(GF)小鼠群维护
  2. 在无菌隔离器中饲养小鼠，提供高压灭菌的食物、水和垫料
  3. 通过定期粪便采样和培养监测无菌状态
  4. 维持无菌繁殖对以产生实验动物

  5. 按年龄和性别匹配实验小鼠(8-12周龄)

  6. 常规(CV)小鼠对照组

  7. 在标准特定病原体清除(SPF)条件下饲养
  8. 与无菌小鼠匹配遗传背景、年龄和性别
  9. 控制饮食组成和喂养计划

  10. 收集粪便样本进行微生物组表征

  11. 组织特异性基因敲除模型构建

  12. 生成肠上皮细胞特异性敲除小鼠(如Nfil3ΔIEC、Hdac3ΔIEC)
  13. 使用Villin-Cre重组酶系统进行IEC特异性删除
  14. 通过PCR确认基因型，通过qPCR/Western blot确认删除效率
  15. 建立繁殖群以产生实验小鼠和同窝对照小鼠

docs.title: 二、微生物组操作实验
docs.text:
1. 细菌菌株分离与表征
  2. 从健康小鼠中分离候选菌株(如乳酸杆菌Pm001)
  3. 进行16S rRNA基因测序进行分类鉴定
  4. 全基因组测序表征功能潜力

  5. 建立纯培养并制备标准化接种物

  6. 细菌灌胃程序

  7. 将细菌培养物制备至特定浓度(10^8-10^9 CFU/ml)
  8. 通过口腔灌胃给无菌小鼠施用200μl细菌悬液
  9. 对照组施用无菌培养基
  10. 通过定期粪便采样和qPCR确认定植

  11. 将小鼠维持在单独隔离器中防止交叉污染

  12. 饮食干预

  13. 配制对照饮食(CD)和高脂饮食(HFD)，成分明确
  14. CD: 10%脂肪、70%碳水化合物、20%蛋白质(按热量)
  15. HFD: 60%脂肪、20%碳水化合物、20%蛋白质(按热量)
  16. 根据实验设计自由采食或配对喂养
  17. 每周2-3次监测食物摄入量和体重

docs.title: 三、表型和代谢评估
docs.text:
1. 体成分分析
  2. 测量整个实验期间的体重变化
  3. 进行DEXA扫描量化脂肪和瘦体重
  4. 测量组织重量(肝脏、附睾脂肪垫、皮下脂肪)

  5. 计算组织与体重比率

  6. 葡萄糖和胰岛素稳态

  7. 进行葡萄糖耐受试验(GTT): 空腹6小时后腹腔注射1-2 g/kg葡萄糖
  8. 进行胰岛素耐受试验(ITT): 空腹4小时后腹腔注射0.75-1 U/kg胰岛素
  9. 测量空腹血糖和胰岛素水平

  10. 计算HOMA-IR指数评估胰岛素抵抗

  11. 脂质代谢分析

  12. 收集血清测量甘油三酯、胆固醇和游离脂肪酸
  13. 使用氯仿/甲醇(2:1)提取肝脏脂质
  14. 使用比色法测定肝脏甘油三酯和胆固醇
  15. 对肝脏切片进行油红O染色可视化脂滴

  16. 在H&E染色的脂肪组织切片中测量脂肪细胞大小

  17. 能量消耗和体力活动

  18. 将小鼠置于代谢笼中测量:
    • 氧气消耗和二氧化碳产生
    • 呼吸交换比(RER)
    • 产热量
    • 活动量
    • 食物和水摄入量

docs.title: 四、分子和细胞分析
docs.text:
1. 转录组分析
  2. 收获组织(肝脏、回肠、结肠)并提取总RNA
  3. 使用Bioanalyzer进行RNA质量控制
  4. 制备RNA-seq文库并测序(Illumina平台)
  5. 分析实验组间差异表达基因
  6. 进行通路富集分析识别被调控的生物学过程

  7. 通过RT-qPCR验证关键基因(如Nfil3、Hdac3、Snhg9)

  8. 蛋白表达分析

  9. 使用适当裂解缓冲液从组织中提取蛋白质
  10. 通过BCA法测定蛋白浓度
  11. 对关键蛋白(NFIL3、HDAC3)进行Western blot分析
  12. 对组织切片进行免疫组织化学染色

  13. 通过免疫共沉淀分析蛋白-蛋白相互作用

  14. 表观遗传学分析

  15. 对HDAC3和其他调节因子进行染色质免疫沉淀(ChIP)
  16. 评估目标基因位点的组蛋白修饰(H3K27ac、H3K4me3)
  17. 使用亚硫酸氢盐测序分析DNA甲基化模式

  18. 使用ATAC-seq研究染色质可及性

  19. 长非编码RNA Snhg9功能分析

  20. 设计并验证靶向Snhg9的siRNA或反义寡核苷酸
  21. 转染原代肝细胞或肠道类器官
  22. 测量对脂质代谢基因和脂质积累的影响
  23. 进行RNA下拉实验鉴定Snhg9蛋白结合伙伴
  24. 使用RNA荧光原位杂交分析亚细胞定位

docs.title: 五、微生物组分析
docs.text:
1. 16S rRNA基因测序
  2. 从粪便样本中提取细菌DNA
  3. 扩增16S rRNA基因的V3-V4区域
  4. 制备测序文库并进行双端测序
  5. 分析分类组成和多样性指标

  6. 比较实验组间微生物群落

  7. 宏基因组测序

  8. 对选定样本进行鸟枪法宏基因组测序
  9. 分析功能基因内容和代谢通路
  10. 鉴定参与脂质代谢的细菌基因

  11. 比较群落间的菌株水平差异

  12. 代谢组学分析

  13. 收集粪便、血清和组织样本进行代谢物提取
  14. 进行非靶向LC-MS/MS或GC-MS分析
  15. 鉴定细菌代谢产物(如短链脂肪酸)
  16. 将代谢物水平与宿主基因表达和表型相关联

docs.title: 六、机制研究
docs.text:
1. 肠道类器官培养
  2. 从实验小鼠分离肠隐窝
  3. 在Matrigel中建立3D类器官培养
  4. 用细菌上清液或纯化代谢物处理类器官

  5. 分析基因表达变化和脂质代谢

  6. 原代肝细胞分离和培养

  7. 从实验小鼠分离原代肝细胞
  8. 在有或无细菌代谢物的定义培养基中培养
  9. 测量脂质合成、氧化和积累

  10. 分析关键代谢基因的表达

  11. 体外细菌-上皮共培养

  12. 建立带有肠上皮细胞的Transwell共培养系统
  13. 在顶端腔室添加乳酸杆菌Pm001或其他细菌菌株
  14. 分析上皮基因表达和屏障功能

  15. 测量细胞因子和趋化因子产生

  16. 细菌代谢物鉴定和测试

  17. 分离细菌培养上清液
  18. 使用质谱鉴定活性代谢物
  19. 合成或纯化候选代谢物
  20. 测试对体外和体内基因表达和脂质代谢的影响

docs.title: 七、数据整合与分析
docs.text:
1. 统计分析
  2. 应用适当统计检验(t检验、ANOVA及事后检验)
  3. 控制多重比较(FDR校正)
  4. 进行功效分析确保足够样本量

  5. 对纵向数据使用线性混合模型

  6. 多组学数据整合

  7. 关联转录组、代谢组和微生物组数据
  8. 进行网络分析识别关键调控枢纽
  9. 使用机器学习方法识别预测性标记

  10. 生成微生物-宿主相互作用的整合模型

  11. 通路建模

  12. 将差异表达基因映射到代谢通路
  13. 识别连接微生物信号与脂质代谢的调控回路
  14. 建模NFIL3-HDAC3-Snhg9调控轴

  15. 基于通路分析预测潜在治疗靶点

  16. 可视化和展示

  17. 生成差异表达基因热图
  18. 创建说明调控机制的通路图
  19. 开发表型数据的清晰图形表示
  20. 准备整合多种数据类型的综合图表

docs.title: 八、验证和转化研究
docs.text:
1. 独立验证队列
  2. 在独立小鼠队列中重复关键实验
  3. 在不同小鼠品系中测试发现，评估通用性
  4. 用替代敲除模型验证(如全身vs组织特异性)

  5. 用多个分离株确认细菌菌株效应

  6. 功能获得性研究

  7. 在相关组织中过表达Nfil3、Hdac3或Snhg9
  8. 评估对脂质代谢和肥胖易感性的影响
  9. 向微生物群失调的小鼠引入乳酸杆菌Pm001

  10. 测试细菌补充是否能挽救代谢表型

  11. 人类相关性评估

  12. 分析人类微生物组数据集中乳酸杆菌丰度
  13. 与人类队列中的代谢参数相关联
  14. 检查人类肠道活检中SNHG9、NFIL3和HDAC3表达

  15. 与代谢疾病患者数据比较发现

  16. 治疗潜力探索

  17. 开发含乳酸杆菌Pm001的益生菌配方
  18. 测试在预防和治疗饮食诱导肥胖中的效果
  19. 探索NFIL3-HDAC3-Snhg9通路的小分子调节剂
  20. 评估靶向多个通路组分的组合方法

docs.title: 九、高级机制研究
docs.text:
1. 昼夜节律分析
  2. 检查Nfil3、Hdac3和Snhg9的时间依赖性表达
  3. 在24小时周期内多个时间点收集组织
  4. 分析微生物群昼夜变化和代谢物产生

  5. 研究限时喂养如何影响该通路

  6. 免疫系统相互作用

  7. 表征肠道组织中的免疫细胞群体
  8. 测量血清和组织匀浆中的细胞因子谱
  9. 研究免疫信号如何影响NFIL3-HDAC3-Snhg9轴

  10. 在免疫缺陷小鼠模型中测试该通路

  11. 胆汁酸代谢研究

  12. 分析肠道内容物和血清中的胆汁酸组成
  13. 分析胆汁酸合成和转运基因表达
  14. 研究乳酸杆菌如何影响胆汁酸代谢

  15. 测试胆汁酸受体激动剂/拮抗剂对通路的影响

  16. 肠道屏障功能评估

Experimental Workflow: Gut Microbiota Regulation of Host Lipid Metabolism

docs.title: I. Animal Model Establishment and Characterization
docs.text:
1. Germ-Free (GF) Mouse Colony Maintenance
  2. House mice in sterile isolators with autoclaved food, water, and bedding
  3. Monitor sterility through regular fecal sampling and culture
  4. Maintain GF breeding pairs to generate experimental animals

  5. Age and sex-match mice for experiments (8-12 weeks old)

  6. Conventional (CV) Mouse Controls

  7. House mice in standard specific-pathogen-free (SPF) conditions
  8. Match genetic background, age, and sex to GF counterparts
  9. Control diet composition and feeding schedule

  10. Collect fecal samples for microbiome characterization

  11. Tissue-Specific Knockout Model Generation

  12. Generate intestinal epithelial cell-specific knockouts (e.g., Nfil3ΔIEC, Hdac3ΔIEC)
  13. Use Villin-Cre recombinase system for IEC-specific deletion
  14. Confirm genotypes by PCR and deletion efficiency by qPCR/Western blot
  15. Establish breeding colonies to generate experimental and littermate control mice

docs.title: II. Microbiota Manipulation Experiments
docs.text:
1. Bacterial Strain Isolation and Characterization
  2. Isolate candidate strains (e.g., Lactobacillus plantarum Pm001) from healthy mice
  3. Perform 16S rRNA gene sequencing for taxonomic identification
  4. Whole-genome sequencing to characterize functional potential

  5. Establish pure cultures and prepare standardized inocula

  6. Bacterial Gavage Procedures

  7. Prepare bacterial cultures to defined concentrations (10^8-10^9 CFU/ml)
  8. Administer 200μl bacterial suspension via oral gavage to GF mice
  9. For control groups, administer sterile culture medium
  10. Establish colonization through regular fecal sampling and qPCR

  11. Maintain mice in separate isolators to prevent cross-contamination

  12. Dietary Interventions

  13. Formulate control diet (CD) and high-fat diet (HFD) with defined composition
  14. CD: 10% fat, 70% carbohydrate, 20% protein by calories
  15. HFD: 60% fat, 20% carbohydrate, 20% protein by calories
  16. Feed mice ad libitum or pair-fed depending on experimental design
  17. Monitor food intake and body weight 2-3 times weekly

docs.title: III. Phenotypic and Metabolic Assessment
docs.text:
1. Body Composition Analysis
  2. Measure body weight progression throughout the experiment
  3. Perform DEXA scanning for fat and lean mass quantification
  4. Measure tissue weights (liver, epididymal fat pad, subcutaneous fat)

  5. Calculate tissue-to-body weight ratios

  6. Glucose and Insulin Homeostasis

  7. Perform glucose tolerance test (GTT): 1-2 g/kg glucose i.p. after 6h fast
  8. Conduct insulin tolerance test (ITT): 0.75-1 U/kg insulin i.p. after 4h fast
  9. Measure fasting blood glucose and insulin levels

  10. Calculate HOMA-IR index for insulin resistance assessment

  11. Lipid Metabolism Analysis

  12. Collect serum for triglyceride, cholesterol, and free fatty acid measurement
  13. Extract liver lipids using chloroform/methanol (2:1) extraction
  14. Quantify hepatic triglycerides and cholesterol using colorimetric assays
  15. Perform Oil Red O staining on liver sections to visualize lipid droplets

  16. Measure adipocyte size in H&E-stained adipose tissue sections

  17. Energy Expenditure and Physical Activity

  18. House mice in metabolic cages to measure:
    • Oxygen consumption and CO2 production
    • Respiratory exchange ratio (RER)
    • Heat production
    • Locomotor activity
    • Food and water intake

docs.title: IV. Molecular and Cellular Analysis
docs.text:
1. Transcriptomic Analysis
  2. Harvest tissues (liver, ileum, colon) and extract total RNA
  3. Perform RNA quality control using Bioanalyzer
  4. Prepare RNA-seq libraries and sequence (Illumina platform)
  5. Analyze differential gene expression between experimental groups
  6. Perform pathway enrichment analysis to identify regulated biological processes

  7. Validate key genes (e.g., Nfil3, Hdac3, Snhg9) by RT-qPCR

  8. Protein Expression Analysis

  9. Extract proteins from tissues using appropriate lysis buffers
  10. Quantify protein concentration by BCA assay
  11. Perform Western blotting for key proteins (NFIL3, HDAC3)
  12. Conduct immunohistochemistry on tissue sections

  13. Analyze protein-protein interactions through co-immunoprecipitation

  14. Epigenetic Analysis

  15. Perform chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) for HDAC3 and other regulators
  16. Assess histone modifications (H3K27ac, H3K4me3) at target gene loci
  17. Analyze DNA methylation patterns using bisulfite sequencing

  18. Investigate chromatin accessibility using ATAC-seq

  19. Functional Analysis of lncRNA Snhg9

  20. Design and validate siRNAs or antisense oligonucleotides targeting Snhg9
  21. Transfect primary hepatocytes or intestinal organoids
  22. Measure effects on lipid metabolism genes and lipid accumulation
  23. Perform RNA pulldown to identify Snhg9 protein binding partners
  24. Analyze subcellular localization using RNA fluorescence in situ hybridization

docs.title: V. Microbiome Analysis
docs.text:
1. 16S rRNA Gene Sequencing
  2. Extract bacterial DNA from fecal samples
  3. Amplify V3-V4 region of 16S rRNA gene
  4. Prepare sequencing libraries and perform paired-end sequencing
  5. Analyze taxonomic composition and diversity metrics

  6. Compare microbial communities between experimental groups

  7. Metagenomic Sequencing

  8. Perform shotgun metagenomic sequencing on select samples
  9. Analyze functional gene content and metabolic pathways
  10. Identify bacterial genes involved in lipid metabolism

  11. Compare strain-level differences between communities

  12. Metabolomic Analysis

  13. Collect fecal, serum, and tissue samples for metabolite extraction
  14. Perform untargeted LC-MS/MS or GC-MS analysis
  15. Identify bacterial metabolites (e.g., short-chain fatty acids)
  16. Correlate metabolite levels with host gene expression and phenotypes

docs.title: VI. Mechanistic Studies
docs.text:
1. Intestinal Organoid Culture
  2. Isolate intestinal crypts from experimental mice
  3. Establish 3D organoid cultures in Matrigel
  4. Treat organoids with bacterial supernatants or purified metabolites

  5. Analyze gene expression changes and lipid metabolism

  6. Primary Hepatocyte Isolation and Culture

  7. Isolate primary hepatocytes from experimental mice
  8. Culture in defined media with or without bacterial metabolites
  9. Measure lipid synthesis, oxidation, and accumulation

  10. Analyze expression of key metabolic genes

  11. In Vitro Bacterial-Epithelial Co-culture

  12. Establish transwell co-culture systems with intestinal epithelial cells
  13. Add L. plantarum Pm001 or other bacterial strains to apical compartment
  14. Analyze epithelial gene expression and barrier function

  15. Measure cytokine and chemokine production

  16. Bacterial Metabolite Identification and Testing

  17. Fractionate bacterial culture supernatants
  18. Identify active metabolites using mass spectrometry
  19. Synthesize or purify candidate metabolites
  20. Test effects on gene expression and lipid metabolism in vitro and in vivo

docs.title: VII. Data Integration and Analysis
docs.text:
1. Statistical Analysis
  2. Apply appropriate statistical tests (t-tests, ANOVA with post-hoc tests)
  3. Control for multiple comparisons (FDR correction)
  4. Perform power analysis to ensure adequate sample sizes
  5. Use linear mixed models for longitudinal data

docs.title: VII. Data Integration and Analysis (continued)
docs.text:
1. Multi-Omics Data Integration (continued)
  2. Correlate transcriptomic, metabolomic, and microbiome data
  3. Perform network analysis to identify key regulatory hubs
  4. Use machine learning approaches to identify predictive signatures

  5. Generate integrative models of microbiota-host interactions

  6. Pathway Modeling

  7. Map differentially expressed genes onto metabolic pathways
  8. Identify regulatory circuits connecting microbiota signals to lipid metabolism
  9. Model the NFIL3-HDAC3-Snhg9 regulatory axis

  10. Predict potential therapeutic targets based on pathway analysis

  11. Visualization and Presentation

  12. Generate heat maps of differentially expressed genes
  13. Create pathway diagrams illustrating regulatory mechanisms
  14. Develop clear graphical representations of phenotypic data
  15. Prepare comprehensive figures integrating multiple data types

docs.title: VIII. Validation and Translational Studies
docs.text:
1. Independent Validation Cohorts
  2. Repeat key experiments in independent mouse cohorts
  3. Test findings in different mouse strains to assess generalizability
  4. Validate with alternative knockout models (e.g., global vs. tissue-specific)

  5. Confirm bacterial strain effects with multiple isolates

  6. Gain-of-Function Studies

  7. Overexpress Nfil3, Hdac3, or Snhg9 in relevant tissues
  8. Assess effects on lipid metabolism and obesity susceptibility
  9. Introduce L. plantarum Pm001 to mice with dysbiotic microbiota

  10. Test if bacterial supplementation can rescue metabolic phenotypes

  11. Human Relevance Assessment

  12. Analyze human microbiome datasets for L. plantarum abundance
  13. Correlate with metabolic parameters in human cohorts
  14. Examine SNHG9, NFIL3, and HDAC3 expression in human intestinal biopsies

  15. Compare findings with data from patients with metabolic disorders

  16. Therapeutic Potential Exploration

  17. Develop probiotic formulations containing L. plantarum Pm001
  18. Test efficacy in prevention and treatment of diet-induced obesity
  19. Explore small molecule modulators of the NFIL3-HDAC3-Snhg9 pathway
  20. Assess combination approaches targeting multiple pathway components

docs.title: IX. Advanced Mechanistic Investigations
docs.text:
1. Circadian Rhythm Analysis
  2. Examine time-dependent expression of Nfil3, Hdac3, and Snhg9
  3. Collect tissues at multiple time points across 24-hour cycle
  4. Analyze microbiota diurnal variations and metabolite production

  5. Investigate how time-restricted feeding affects the pathway

  6. Immune System Interactions

  7. Characterize immune cell populations in intestinal tissue
  8. Measure cytokine profiles in serum and tissue homogenates
  9. Investigate how immune signaling affects the NFIL3-HDAC3-Snhg9 axis

  10. Test the pathway in immune-deficient mouse models

  11. Bile Acid Metabolism Studies

  12. Profile bile acid composition in intestinal content and serum
  13. Analyze expression of bile acid synthesis and transport genes
  14. Investigate how L. plantarum affects bile acid metabolism

  15. Test bile acid receptor agonists/antagonists for pathway effects

  16. Intestinal Barrier Function Assessment

  17. Measure intestinal permeability using FITC-dextran assay
  18. Analyze tight junction protein expression and localization
  19. Investigate how barrier integrity affects lipid metabolism
  20. Test if L. plantarum improves barrier function in HFD-fed mice

docs.title: X. Clinical Translation and Future Directions
docs.text:
1. Pilot Human Studies
  2. Design small-scale clinical trials with L. plantarum supplementation
  3. Target patients with metabolic syndrome or non-alcoholic fatty liver disease
  4. Measure changes in lipid profiles, glucose metabolism, and inflammation

  5. Collect fecal samples for microbiome analysis and SNHG9 expression

  6. Biomarker Development

  7. Identify circulating biomarkers associated with pathway activation
  8. Develop assays to measure bacterial metabolites in human samples
  9. Create diagnostic panels to identify patients likely to respond to intervention

  10. Validate biomarkers in prospective clinical cohorts

  11. Personalized Intervention Strategies

  12. Stratify individuals based on baseline microbiome composition
  13. Develop algorithms to predict responders to L. plantarum supplementation
  14. Design personalized dietary recommendations to support beneficial bacteria

  15. Test combined approaches (probiotics + diet) for maximal efficacy

  16. Long-term Safety and Efficacy Monitoring

  17. Establish protocols for long-term follow-up
  18. Monitor for potential adverse effects of microbiome manipulation
  19. Assess durability of metabolic improvements
  20. Investigate potential for combining with existing metabolic therapies

This comprehensive experimental workflow enables researchers to thoroughly investigate the molecular mechanisms by which gut microbiota, particularly L. plantarum Pm001, regulates host lipid metabolism through the NFIL3-HDAC3-Snhg9 axis. The approach integrates multiple levels of analysis—from microbiome to transcriptome to metabolic phenotype—providing a systems-level understanding of host-microbe interactions in metabolic health and disease.

docs.title: 1. Experimental Purpose:
docs.text:
• Scientific Question: The study aims to understand how the gut microbiota regulates host lipid metabolism and how dysbiosis (imbalance in the microbiota) contributes to metabolic disorders such as obesity and diabetes. Specifically, the study investigates the role of Nfil3, Hdac3, and Snhg9 in mediating the effects of the microbiota on lipid metabolism.
  • Experimental Design: The study uses germ-free (GF) mice and conventional (CV) mice to identify key genes regulated by the microbiota. The researchers then use gene knockout models and bacterial gavage to study the functional roles of these genes and specific bacterial strains in lipid metabolism.

docs.title: 2. Model System:
docs.text:
• Model System: The study primarily uses germ-free (GF) mice and conventional (CV) mice. These models are ideal for studying the effects of the microbiota on host metabolism because GF mice lack a gut microbiota, allowing researchers to isolate the effects of specific bacterial strains.
  • Why This System?: Mice are appropriate for this study because their gut microbiota and lipid metabolism are well-characterized, and they allow for precise genetic manipulation. The use of GF mice is particularly relevant because it enables researchers to study the effects of specific bacterial strains on host metabolism.
  • Alternative Model Systems: Other model systems like zebrafish or Drosophila could be used, but they lack the complexity of mammalian lipid metabolism and gut microbiota interactions.
  • Ethical Considerations: Using mice requires ethical approval, especially when dealing with germ-free conditions and dietary interventions. The study likely adheres to ethical guidelines for animal research.

docs.title: 3. Measurement Approach:
docs.text:
• Techniques: The study employs several techniques:
    • RNA sequencing (RNA-seq): To identify genes regulated by the microbiota.
    • Biochemical assays: To measure lipid levels and metabolic activity.
    • Gene knockout models: To study the functional roles of Nfil3, Hdac3, and Snhg9 in lipid metabolism.
    • Bacterial gavage: To introduce specific bacterial strains (e.g., Lactobacillus plantarum Pm001) into GF mice and study their effects on lipid metabolism.
  • Why These Methods?: RNA-seq was chosen to identify genes regulated by the microbiota, while biochemical assays were used to measure lipid levels and metabolic activity. Gene knockout models and bacterial gavage were used to study the functional roles of specific genes and bacterial strains.
  • Technical Replicates: The study likely uses multiple replicates (e.g., n=3 or more) to ensure the robustness of the data.
  • Potential Biases: Biases could arise from differences in mouse strains or dietary conditions. These are minimized by using standardized protocols and controls.

docs.title: 4. Group Setting:
docs.text:
• Experimental Groups: The study compares several groups:
    • Germ-free (GF) mice vs. conventional (CV) mice: To study the effects of the microbiota on lipid metabolism.
    • Gene knockout mice (e.g., Nfil3ΔIEC, Hdac3ΔIEC) vs. wild-type mice: To study the functional roles of specific genes in lipid metabolism.
    • Mice treated with specific bacterial strains (e.g., Lactobacillus plantarum Pm001) vs. control mice: To study the effects of specific bacterial strains on lipid metabolism.
  • Negative Controls: GF mice and wild-type mice serve as negative controls to study the effects of the microbiota and gene knockouts on lipid metabolism.
  • Biological Replicates: Multiple mice are used in each group (e.g., n=8) to ensure reproducibility.
  • Modified Group Design: A dose-response experiment could be added to study how varying levels of specific bacterial strains or gene expression affect lipid metabolism.

docs.title: 5. Data Analysis & Presentation:
docs.text:
• Data Processing: Raw RNA-seq data are processed to identify differentially expressed genes. Biochemical data are analyzed to measure lipid levels and metabolic activity.
  • Statistical Tests: The study uses statistical methods (e.g., t-tests, ANOVA) to compare gene expression and lipid levels between groups. Differential expression analysis is performed to identify key genes regulated by the microbiota.
  • Data Presentation: Results are presented using graphs and tables, which are clear and free of misleading scaling. For example, the study uses bar graphs to compare lipid levels and scatter plots to show gene expression changes.
  • Confirmation: The findings are confirmed using gene knockout models and bacterial gavage, which validate the role of specific genes and bacterial strains in regulating lipid metabolism.

docs.title: General Observations:
docs.text:
• The study provides a detailed understanding of how the gut microbiota regulates host lipid metabolism through specific genes (Nfil3, Hdac3, and Snhg9).
  • The findings highlight the importance of Lactobacillus plantarum Pm001 in promoting Snhg9 expression and protecting mice from diet-induced obesity.
  • The results have significant implications for understanding the molecular basis of microbiota-host interactions and developing microbiota-based therapies for metabolic disorders.

docs.title: Experimental Workflow: IL-33 Regulation of Cold-Induced Thermogenesis
I. Animal Model Preparation and Cold Exposure Protocol
docs.text:
1. Mouse Strain Selection and Housing
  2. Select C57BL/6J mice (8-12 weeks old, both sexes or sex-matched)
  3. House in standard conditions (22°C, 12h light/dark cycle)
  4. For germ-free experiments, maintain mice in sterile isolators

  5. Acclimate mice to housing conditions for at least 1 week

  6. Cold Exposure Protocol

  7. Divide mice into experimental groups:
    • Room temperature controls (22°C)
    • Acute cold exposure (6°C for 24-48h)
    • Chronic cold exposure (6°C for 7-14 days)
  8. Transfer mice to pre-cooled cages with adequate bedding
  9. Monitor body temperature using rectal probe thermometer

  10. Record food intake and body weight daily

  11. Genetic Model Generation

  12. Generate cell-specific knockout models:
    • PDGFRβ-specific Cre mice crossed with IL-33flox/flox
    • CREB conditional knockout mice
  13. Validate knockout efficiency by qPCR and Western blot
  14. Generate reporter mice (e.g., IL-33-GFP) for cell tracking. This means that cells actively transcribing the IL-33 gene will also produce GFP, making them fluorescent and detectable by flow cytometry or fluorescence microscopy.

docs.title: II. Adipose Tissue Analysis and Cell Isolation
docs.text:
1. Tissue Collection and Processing
  2. Euthanize mice according to ethical guidelines
  3. Collect inguinal white adipose tissue (iWAT), epididymal WAT, and brown adipose tissue (BAT)

  4. Weigh tissues and divide for:

    • Snap freezing in liquid nitrogen (gene/protein analysis)
    • Fixation in 4% paraformaldehyde (histology)
    • Fresh processing (cell isolation)

  5. Histological Analysis

  6. Process fixed tissues for paraffin embedding or OCT-compound frozen sections
  7. Section tissues at 5-8μm thickness
  8. Perform H&E staining for morphological analysis
  9. Conduct UCP1 immunohistochemistry to identify beige adipocytes

  10. Image using light microscopy and quantify beige adipocyte areas

  11. Adipose Tissue Fractionation

  12. Mince fresh adipose tissue and digest with collagenase
  13. Centrifuge to separate floating adipocytes from stromal vascular fraction (SVF)
  14. Filter SVF through 70μm strainer
  15. Lyse red blood cells if necessary

  16. Count cells using hemocytometer or automated cell counter

  17. PDGFRβ+DPP4+ Cell Isolation

  18. Stain SVF with fluorescent antibodies:
    • Anti-PDGFRβ (CD140b)
    • Anti-DPP4 (CD26)
    • Lineage markers (CD31, CD45) for exclusion
  19. Perform fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS)
  20. Collect PDGFRβ+DPP4+ and PDGFRβ+DPP4- populations
  21. Verify purity by flow cytometry analysis of a sample aliquot

docs.title: III. Molecular and Cellular Analysis
docs.text:
1. RNA Sequencing and Transcriptome Analysis
  2. Extract total RNA from:
    • Whole adipose tissue samples
    • Sorted PDGFRβ+DPP4+ cells
    • Other relevant cell populations
  3. Assess RNA quality (Bioanalyzer, RNA integrity number >8)
  4. Prepare RNA-seq libraries (poly-A selection or ribo-depletion)
  5. Perform paired-end sequencing (Illumina platform)

  6. Analyze data using standard bioinformatics pipeline:

    • Quality control and read alignment
    • Differential expression analysis
    • Pathway enrichment analysis
    • Visualization (heatmaps, volcano plots)

  7. Gene Expression Analysis

  8. Design primers for key genes (IL-33, UCP1, PGC1α, CREB, etc.)
  9. Perform RT-qPCR on tissue and cell samples
  10. Normalize to housekeeping genes (β-actin, GAPDH)
  11. Calculate relative expression using 2^-ΔΔCt method

  12. Validate RNA-seq findings for selected genes

  13. Protein Expression Analysis

  14. Extract proteins from tissues and cells
  15. Quantify protein concentration (BCA assay)
  16. Perform Western blotting for:
    • IL-33 and its receptor ST2
    • UCP1 and other thermogenic markers
    • CREB and phospho-CREB
    • Signaling pathway components

  17. Conduct ELISA to measure IL-33 levels in tissue and serum

  18. Flow Cytometry Analysis of Immune Cells

  19. Prepare single-cell suspensions from SVF
  20. Stain with antibodies for:
    • ILC2s (Lineage-CD45+KLRG1+ST2+)
    • Eosinophils (CD11b+Siglec-F+)
    • Other immune cell populations
  21. Analyze using multicolor flow cytometry
  22. Quantify cell numbers and percentages
  23. Assess activation status through marker expression

docs.title: IV. Functional Studies and Mechanistic Investigations
docs.text:
1. CRISPR/Cas9 Gene Editing
  2. Design sgRNAs targeting CREB binding sites in IL-33 promoter
  3. Validate sgRNA efficiency in cell culture
  4. Transfect PDGFRβ+DPP4+ cells or use in vivo delivery methods
  5. Confirm editing by sequencing and functional assays

  6. Assess effects on IL-33 expression and cold response

  7. Chromatin Immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

  8. Crosslink proteins to DNA in adipose tissue or isolated cells
  9. Sonicate chromatin to appropriate fragment size
  10. Immunoprecipitate with anti-CREB antibody
  11. Purify DNA and perform qPCR for IL-33 promoter regions
  12. For genome-wide analysis, perform ChIP-seq

  13. Analyze binding sites and motifs using bioinformatics tools

  14. In Vitro Cell Culture Studies

  15. Establish primary cultures of PDGFRβ+DPP4+ cells
  16. Treat cells with:
    • β-adrenergic agonists (e.g., isoproterenol)
    • cAMP analogs to mimic cold stimulation
    • CREB inhibitors or activators
  17. Measure IL-33 expression and secretion
  18. Perform co-culture experiments with adipocyte precursors

  19. Assess effects on adipogenic and thermogenic gene expression

  20. In Vivo Functional Assays

  21. Perform metabolic cage studies to measure:
    • Oxygen consumption and CO2 production
    • Energy expenditure
    • Physical activity
  22. Conduct glucose and insulin tolerance tests
  23. Measure core body temperature during cold challenge
  24. Use infrared thermography to assess heat production

docs.title: V. Intervention Studies and Pathway Validation
docs.text:
1. IL-33 Administration and Neutralization
  2. Administer recombinant IL-33 to mice at room temperature
  3. Neutralize IL-33 using anti-IL-33 antibodies during cold exposure

  4. Assess effects on:

    • Beige adipocyte formation
    • UCP1 expression
    • Thermogenic capacity
    • ILC2 recruitment and activation

  5. ILC2 Depletion and Reconstitution

  6. Deplete ILC2s using anti-CD90.2 or genetic approaches
  7. Reconstitute with adoptive transfer of sorted ILC2s
  8. Evaluate the necessity of ILC2s for IL-33-mediated thermogenesis

  9. Analyze downstream mediators (e.g., IL-4, IL-13)

  10. Pharmacological Interventions

  11. Target CREB pathway using specific inhibitors
  12. Modulate β-adrenergic signaling with agonists/antagonists
  13. Assess effects on IL-33 expression and thermogenic remodeling

  14. Identify potential therapeutic targets

  15. Microbiome Studies (for GF vs. CV comparison)

  16. Collect fecal samples for 16S rRNA sequencing
  17. Compare microbiome composition between temperature conditions
  18. Perform fecal microbiota transplantation experiments
  19. Analyze correlations between specific bacterial taxa and IL-33 expression

docs.title: VI. Data Integration and Analysis
docs.text:
1. Statistical Analysis
  2. Apply appropriate statistical tests:
    • Student's t-test for two-group comparisons
    • ANOVA with post-hoc tests for multiple groups
    • Non-parametric tests for non-normal distributions
  3. Control for multiple comparisons (Benjamini-Hochberg)
  4. Ensure adequate power through appropriate sample sizes

  5. Present data as mean ± SEM with individual data points

  6. Multi-omics Integration

  7. Correlate transcriptomic data with protein expression
  8. Integrate ChIP-seq with RNA-seq to identify direct CREB targets
  9. Link cellular composition with functional outcomes

  10. Develop pathway models of IL-33-mediated thermogenesis

  11. Visualization and Presentation

  12. Create clear figures showing key findings
  13. Use consistent color schemes and labeling
  14. Include appropriate controls in all data presentations
  15. Develop schematic models summarizing the mechanism

This comprehensive experimental workflow enables detailed investigation of how IL-33 produced by PDGFRβ+DPP4+ cells regulates cold-induced thermogenesis, from the initial cold stimulus to CREB activation, IL-33 production, ILC2 recruitment, and ultimate beige adipocyte formation. The approach integrates multiple techniques spanning molecular biology, cell biology, and physiology to provide a complete understanding of this important metabolic pathway.

docs.title: 实验工作流程：IL-33调控冷诱导产热
一、动物模型准备和冷暴露方案
docs.text:
1. 小鼠品系选择与饲养
  2. 选择C57BL/6J小鼠(8-12周龄，两性或性别匹配)
  3. 在标准条件下饲养(22°C，12小时光照/黑暗周期)
  4. 对于无菌实验，将小鼠维持在无菌隔离器中

  5. 使小鼠适应饲养条件至少1周

  6. 冷暴露方案

  7. 将小鼠分为实验组：
    • 室温对照组(22°C)
    • 急性冷暴露组(6°C持续24-48小时)
    • 慢性冷暴露组(6°C持续7-14天)
  8. 将小鼠转移到预冷却的笼子中，提供足够垫料
  9. 使用直肠温度计监测体温

  10. 每日记录食物摄入量和体重

  11. 基因模型构建

  12. 生成细胞特异性敲除模型：
    • PDGFRβ特异性Cre小鼠与IL-33flox/flox交配
    • CREB条件性敲除小鼠
  13. 通过qPCR和Western blot验证敲除效率
  14. 生成报告基因小鼠(如IL-33-GFP)用于细胞追踪

docs.title: 二、脂肪组织分析和细胞分离
docs.text:
1. 组织收集和处理
  2. 按照伦理指南安乐死小鼠
  3. 收集腹股沟白色脂肪组织(iWAT)、附睾白色脂肪组织和棕色脂肪组织(BAT)

  4. 称重组织并分为：

    • 液氮快速冷冻(基因/蛋白分析)
    • 4%多聚甲醛固定(组织学)
    • 新鲜处理(细胞分离)

  5. 组织学分析

  6. 处理固定组织进行石蜡包埋或OCT冷冻切片
  7. 将组织切片厚度为5-8μm
  8. 进行H&E染色进行形态学分析
  9. 进行UCP1免疫组织化学染色识别米色脂肪细胞

  10. 使用光学显微镜成像并量化米色脂肪细胞面积

  11. 脂肪组织分离

  12. 剪碎新鲜脂肪组织并用胶原酶消化
  13. 离心分离浮游脂肪细胞和基质血管部分(SVF)
  14. 通过70μm滤网过滤SVF
  15. 必要时溶解红细胞

  16. 使用血球计数器或自动细胞计数器计数

  17. PDGFRβ+DPP4+细胞分离

  18. 用荧光抗体染色SVF：
    • 抗PDGFRβ(CD140b)
    • 抗DPP4(CD26)
    • 谱系标记物(CD31, CD45)用于排除
  19. 进行荧光激活细胞分选(FACS)
  20. 收集PDGFRβ+DPP4+和PDGFRβ+DPP4-细胞群
  21. 通过流式细胞术分析样品等分验证纯度

docs.title: 三、分子和细胞分析
docs.text:
1. RNA测序和转录组分析
  2. 从以下样本提取总RNA：
    • 整个脂肪组织样本
    • 分选的PDGFRβ+DPP4+细胞
    • 其他相关细胞群
  3. 评估RNA质量(Bioanalyzer，RNA完整性数值>8)
  4. 制备RNA-seq文库(poly-A选择或ribo-depletion)
  5. 进行双端测序(Illumina平台)

  6. 使用标准生物信息学流程分析数据：

    • 质量控制和读段比对
    • 差异表达分析
    • 通路富集分析
    • 可视化(热图，火山图)

  7. 基因表达分析

  8. 设计关键基因引物(IL-33, UCP1, PGC1α, CREB等)
  9. 对组织和细胞样本进行RT-qPCR
  10. 使用看家基因(β-actin, GAPDH)标准化
  11. 使用2^-ΔΔCt方法计算相对表达

  12. 验证选定基因的RNA-seq发现

  13. 蛋白表达分析

  14. 从组织和细胞中提取蛋白质
  15. 测定蛋白质浓度(BCA法)
  16. 进行以下Western blot：
    • IL-33及其受体ST2
    • UCP1和其他产热标记物
    • CREB和磷酸化CREB
    • 信号通路组分

  17. 进行ELISA测量组织和血清中IL-33水平

  18. 免疫细胞流式细胞术分析

  19. 从SVF制备单细胞悬液
  20. 用以下抗体染色：
    • ILC2s(Lineage-CD45+KLRG1+ST2+)
    • 嗜酸性粒细胞(CD11b+Siglec-F+)
    • 其他免疫细胞群
  21. 使用多色流式细胞术分析
  22. 量化细胞数量和百分比
  23. 通过标记物表达评估激活状态

docs.title: 四、功能研究和机制调查
docs.text:
1. CRISPR/Cas9基因编辑
  2. 设计靶向IL-33启动子中CREB结合位点的sgRNAs
  3. 在细胞培养中验证sgRNA效率
  4. 转染PDGFRβ+DPP4+细胞或使用体内递送方法
  5. 通过测序和功能测定确认编辑

  6. 评估对IL-33表达和冷响应的影响

  7. 染色质免疫沉淀(ChIP)

  8. 在脂肪组织或分离的细胞中将蛋白质与DNA交联
  9. 将染色质超声处理至适当片段大小
  10. 用抗CREB抗体进行免疫沉淀
  11. 纯化DNA并对IL-33启动子区域进行qPCR
  12. 对于全基因组分析，进行ChIP-seq

  13. 使用生物信息学工具分析结合位点和基序

  14. 体外细胞培养研究

  15. 建立PDGFRβ+DPP4+细胞的原代培养
  16. 用以下物质处理细胞：
    • β-肾上腺素能激动剂(如异丙肾上腺素)
    • cAMP类似物模拟冷刺激
    • CREB抑制剂或激活剂
  17. 测量IL-33表达和分泌
  18. 进行与脂肪细胞前体的共培养实验

  19. 评估对脂肪生成和产热基因表达的影响

  20. 体内功能测定

  21. 进行代谢笼研究测量：
    • 氧气消耗和CO2产生
    • 能量消耗
    • 体力活动
  22. 进行葡萄糖和胰岛素耐受性测试
  23. 在冷挑战期间测量核心体温
  24. 使用红外热成像评估产热

docs.title: 五、干预研究和通路验证
docs.text:
1. IL-33给药和中和
  2. 在室温下给小鼠施用重组IL-33
  3. 在冷暴露期间使用抗IL-33抗体中和IL-33

  4. 评估对以下方面的影响：

    • 米色脂肪细胞形成
    • UCP1表达
    • 产热能力
    • ILC2招募和激活

  5. ILC2清除和重建

  6. 使用抗CD90.2或基因方法清除ILC2s
  7. 通过分选的ILC2s过继转移进行重建
  8. 评估ILC2对IL-33介导产热的必要性

  9. 分析下游介质(如IL-4, IL-13)

  10. 药理学干预

  11. 使用特定抑制剂靶向CREB通路
  12. 用激动剂/拮抗剂调节β-肾上腺素能信号
  13. 评估对IL-33表达和产热重塑的影响

  14. 确定潜在的治疗靶点

  15. 微生物组研究(用于GF vs CV比较)

  16. 收集粪便样本进行16S rRNA测序
  17. 比较不同温度条件下的微生物组成
  18. 进行粪便微生物群移植实验
  19. 分析特定细菌类群与IL-33表达之间的相关性

docs.title: 六、数据整合和分析
docs.text:
1. 统计分析
  2. 应用适当的统计检验：
    • 两组比较使用Student's t检验
    • 多组使用ANOVA及事后检验
    • 非正态分布使用非参数检验
  3. 控制多重比较(Benjamini-Hochberg)
  4. 通过适当的样本量确保足够的统计功效

  5. 将数据呈现为均值±标准误差，并显示个体数据点

  6. 多组学整合

  7. 将转录组数据与蛋白表达相关联
  8. 整合ChIP-seq与RNA-seq识别直接CREB靶点
  9. 将细胞组成与功能结果联系起来

  10. 开发IL-33介导产热的通路模型

  11. 可视化和展示

  12. 创建显示关键发现的清晰图表
  13. 使用一致的配色方案和标签
  14. 在所有数据展示中包含适当的对照
  15. 开发总结机制的示意模型

这一综合实验工作流程使研究人员能够详细研究PDGFRβ+DPP4+细胞产生的IL-33如何调控冷诱导产热，从最初的冷刺激到CREB激活、IL-33产生、ILC2招募，最终形成米色脂肪细胞。该方法整合了跨越分子生物学、细胞生物学和生理学的多种技术，提供了对这一重要代谢通路的完整理解。

docs.title: 1. Experimental Purpose:
docs.text:
• Scientific Question: The study aims to understand how IL-33, a cytokine produced by PDGFRβ+DPP4+ cells, regulates cold-induced thermogenesis and the formation of beige adipocytes in white adipose tissue (WAT). Specifically, the study investigates whether IL-33 expression is induced by cold exposure and how it contributes to thermogenic remodeling.
  • Experimental Design: The study uses a combination of RNA sequencing (RNA-seq), flow cytometry, histology, and CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing to explore the role of IL-33 in cold-induced thermogenesis. The researchers first identify IL-33 as a key player in the process and then investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying its regulation.

docs.title: 2. Model System:
docs.text:
• Model System: The study primarily uses mouse models, particularly PDGFRβ+DPP4+ cells in inguinal(腹股沟的) white adipose tissue (iWAT). These cells are identified as the main source of IL-33 in iWAT. The study also uses germ-free (GF) and conventional (CV) mice to study the effects of cold exposure on adipose tissue.
  • Why This System?: Mice are appropriate for this study because they allow for the manipulation of specific cell populations and genes, and their adipose tissue responds to cold exposure in a manner similar to humans. The use of PDGFRβ+DPP4+ cells is relevant because these cells are known to play a role in adipose tissue remodeling.
  • Alternative Model Systems: Other model systems, such as cell cultures or zebrafish, could be used, but they lack the complexity of in vivo adipose tissue remodeling and the interaction between different cell types.
  • Ethical Considerations: Using mice requires ethical approval, especially when dealing with cold exposure and gene editing. The study likely adheres to ethical guidelines for animal research.

docs.title: 3. Measurement Approach:
docs.text:
• Techniques: The study employs several techniques:
    • RNA-seq: To analyze gene expression changes in response to cold exposure.
    • Flow cytometry: To study immune cell populations (e.g., ILC2s,一种调节脂肪的免疫细胞) in adipose tissue.
    • Histology: To visualize beige adipocyte formation in adipose tissue.
    • CRISPR/Cas9: To knock out CREB, a transcription factor that regulates IL-33 expression.
    • Chromatin Immunoprecipitation (ChIP): To study the binding of CREB to the IL-33 promoter.
  • Why These Methods?: RNA-seq was chosen to identify genes regulated by cold exposure, while flow cytometry and histology were used to study the cellular and tissue-level effects of IL-33. CRISPR/Cas9 and ChIP assays were used to investigate the molecular mechanisms of IL-33 regulation.
  • Technical Replicates: The study likely uses multiple replicates (e.g., n=4 or more) to ensure the robustness of the data.
  • Potential Biases: Biases could arise from differences in mouse strains or environmental conditions. These are minimized by using standardized protocols and controls.

docs.title: 4. Group Setting:
docs.text:
• Experimental Groups: The study compares several groups:
    • Cold-exposed mice (6°C) vs. room temperature mice (22°C): To study the effects of cold exposure on IL-33 expression and thermogenic remodeling.
    • PDGFRβ+DPP4+ cells vs. PDGFRβ+DPP4- cells: To identify the source of IL-33 in iWAT.
    • CREB knockout mice vs. wild-type mice: To study the role of CREB in regulating IL-33 expression.
  • Negative Controls: Mice kept at room temperature and wild-type mice serve as negative controls to study the effects of cold exposure and CREB knockout.
  • Biological Replicates: Multiple mice are used in each group (e.g., n=8) to ensure reproducibility.
  • Modified Group Design: A dose-response experiment could be added to study how varying levels of cold exposure or IL-33 expression affect thermogenic remodeling.

docs.title: 5. Data Analysis & Presentation:
docs.text:
• Data Processing: Raw RNA-seq data are processed to identify differentially expressed genes. Flow cytometry and histology data are analyzed to study cell populations and tissue remodeling. ChIP assay data are analyzed to study the binding of CREB to the IL-33 promoter.
  • Statistical Tests: The study uses statistical methods (e.g., t-tests, ANOVA) to compare gene expression, cell populations, and transcription factor binding between groups. Differential expression analysis is performed to identify key genes regulated by cold exposure and IL-33.
  • Data Presentation: Results are presented using graphs, tables, and histological images, which are clear and free of misleading scaling. For example, the study uses volcano plots to show differentially expressed genes and bar graphs to compare IL-33 expression levels.
  • Confirmation: The findings are confirmed using gene knockout models (e.g., CREB knockout) and functional assays (e.g., ChIP assays), which validate the role of IL-33 and CREB in cold-induced thermogenesis.

docs.title: General Observations:
docs.text:
• The study provides a detailed understanding of how IL-33, produced by PDGFRβ+DPP4+ cells, regulates cold-induced thermogenesis and beige adipocyte formation.
  • The findings highlight the importance of CREB as a transcription factor that drives IL-33 expression in response to cold exposure.
  • The results have significant implications for understanding the molecular basis of cold-induced thermogenesis and developing therapies for obesity and metabolic disorders.

docs.title: S2.W1.1. Seminar. Deep learning for genomics modeling and interpretation
1. Translatorner: A Transformer-based Model for mRNA Translation
Experimental Purpose:
docs.text:
• Scientific Question: The study aims to understand the regulation of mRNA translation and its impact on protein abundance, which is crucial for understanding disease mechanisms. The central dogma of biology (DNA → RNA → Protein) is well-known, but the correlation between mRNA and protein levels is not perfect (0.39 to 0.79). The study seeks to model how mRNA translation is regulated and how this regulation affects protein levels.
  • Experimental Design: The study uses a Transformer-based deep learning model (Translatorner) to predict ribosome profiling (translatome) from RNA-seq data and gene sequences. The model is trained on human data and tested on both human and mouse datasets to evaluate its ability to generalize across species.

docs.title: Model System:
docs.text:
• Model System: The study uses human and mouse genomic data. These systems are appropriate because they are well-studied, and the conservation of regulatory mechanisms between humans and mice allows for cross-species validation.
  • Alternative Model Systems: Other model systems like yeast or zebrafish could be used, but they may lack the complexity and relevance to human diseases. However, they are cheaper and easier to manipulate.
  • Ethical Considerations: Using human genomic data requires ethical approval, especially when dealing with patient data. The study likely adheres to ethical guidelines for genomic research.

docs.title: Measurement Approach:
docs.text:
• Techniques: The study uses ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) and RNA-seq data. These are quantitative techniques that measure translation efficiency and mRNA abundance, respectively.
  • Method Choice: Deep learning models (Transformers) were chosen because they can capture long-range dependencies in sequences, which is crucial for understanding translation regulation.
  • Technical Replicates: The study likely uses multiple replicates to ensure robustness, though the exact number is not specified.
  • Potential Biases: Biases could arise from data normalization or sequencing depth. These are minimized by using standardized protocols and cross-validation.

docs.title: Group Setting:
docs.text:
• Experimental Groups: The model is trained on human data and tested on both human and mouse data. The groups are defined by cell types (e.g., epithelial cells, brain cells).
  • Negative Controls: The study compares Translatorner with state-of-the-art models (e.g., Riboformer) to ensure that the improvements are not due to overfitting.
  • Biological Replicates: The study uses multiple datasets (e.g., K562, epithelial cells) to ensure generalizability.
  • Modified Group Design: A dose-response experiment could be added to study how varying levels of mRNA affect translation efficiency.

docs.title: Data Analysis & Presentation:
docs.text:
• Data Processing: Raw data from Ribo-seq and RNA-seq are processed using deep learning models. The data are quantitative, and the model outputs are compared with experimental data.
  • Statistical Tests: The study uses Pearson correlation coefficients (PCC) to compare predicted and observed ribosome profiling data.
  • Data Presentation: Results are presented using scatter plots and enrichment plots, which are clear and free of misleading scaling.
  • Confirmation: The model's predictions are validated using cross-species data and in silico mutagenesis, which confirms the robustness of the results.

docs.title: 2. TransRBP: Modeling RBP Binding and Its Interaction with m6A
Experimental Purpose:
docs.text:
• Scientific Question: The study aims to understand how RNA-binding proteins (RBPs) interact with m6A modifications and how these interactions affect RNA metabolism and disease.
  • Experimental Design: The study develops a deep learning model (TransRBP) to predict RBP binding sites and their interaction with m6A. The model is trained on RNA sequences and tested for its ability to identify disease-related variants that alter RBP binding.

docs.title: Model System:
docs.text:
• Model System: The study uses human genomic data, focusing on RBPs and m6A modifications. This system is appropriate because m6A is the most prevalent mRNA modification and plays a critical role in RNA metabolism.
  • Alternative Model Systems: Other systems like yeast or bacteria could be used, but they lack the complexity of m6A regulation seen in higher eukaryotes.
  • Ethical Considerations: Similar to Translatorner, the use of human genomic data requires ethical approval.

docs.title: Measurement Approach:
docs.text:

1. Experimental Purpose:
docs.text:
• Scientific Question: The study aims to understand how histone modifications (e.g., acetylation, methylation) and chromatin structure regulate transcription. Specifically, it investigates the structural mechanisms by which histone modifications influence the binding of transcription machinery and the regulation of gene expression.
  • Experimental Design: The study uses structural biology techniques (e.g., cryo-EM, X-ray crystallography) to determine the molecular structures of key epigenetic regulators, such as histone acetyltransferases (HATs) and histone deacetylases (HDACs), and their interactions with nucleosomes and transcription factors.

docs.title: 2. Model System:
docs.text:
• Model System: The study primarily uses yeast and human cells, as these systems are well-characterized and provide a direct link to eukaryotic transcription regulation. The study focuses on the SAGA complex, a well-known HAT complex involved in transcription regulation.
  • Why This System?: Yeast and human cells are appropriate for this study because they allow for the manipulation of specific histone modifications and chromatin structures. The SAGA complex is relevant because it plays a key role in regulating transcription through histone acetylation.
  • Alternative Model Systems: Other model systems like bacteria or plants could be used, but they lack the complexity of eukaryotic chromatin and histone modifications.
  • Ethical Considerations: Using human cell lines requires ethical approval, especially when dealing with patient-derived samples. The study likely adheres to ethical guidelines for genomic research.

docs.title: 3. Measurement Approach:
docs.text:
• Techniques: The study employs several techniques:
    • Cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM): To determine the structures of epigenetic regulators (e.g., SAGA complex) and their interactions with nucleosomes.
    • X-ray crystallography: To obtain high-resolution structures of specific histone modifications and their interactions with transcription factors.
    • Biochemical assays: To study the functional roles of histone modifications in transcription regulation.
    • Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP): To study the binding of transcription factors to histone-modified chromatin.
  • Why These Methods?: Cryo-EM and X-ray crystallography were chosen because they allow for the visualization of molecular structures at atomic resolution, which is crucial for understanding the mechanisms of epigenetic regulation. Biochemical assays and ChIP were used to study the functional roles of histone modifications in transcription.
  • Technical Replicates: The study likely uses multiple replicates (e.g., n=3 or more) to ensure the robustness of the structural data.
  • Potential Biases: Biases could arise from sample preparation or data interpretation. These are minimized by using standardized protocols and cross-validation with biochemical assays.

docs.title: 4. Group Setting:
docs.text:
• Experimental Groups: The study compares several groups:
    • Wild-type cells vs. cells with specific histone modifications: To study the effects of histone modifications on transcription.
    • Cells with intact SAGA complex vs. cells with SAGA complex mutations: To study the role of the SAGA complex in transcription regulation.
    • Cells treated with HDAC inhibitors vs. untreated cells: To study the effects of histone deacetylation on transcription.
  • Negative Controls: Cells without specific histone modifications or with intact SAGA complex serve as negative controls to study the effects of histone modifications and SAGA complex mutations.
  • Biological Replicates: Multiple samples are used in each group (e.g., n=3 or more) to ensure reproducibility.
  • Modified Group Design: A dose-response experiment could be added to study how varying levels of histone modifications or HDAC inhibitors affect transcription.

docs.title: 5. Data Analysis & Presentation:
docs.text:
• Data Processing: Raw structural data from cryo-EM and X-ray crystallography are processed to generate 3D models of the molecular structures. Biochemical and ChIP data are analyzed to study the functional roles of histone modifications in transcription.
  • Statistical Tests: The study uses statistical validation methods (e.g., cross-validation, resolution assessment) to ensure the accuracy of the structural models. Differential binding analysis is performed to identify key transcription factors regulated by histone modifications.
  • Data Presentation: Results are presented using 3D structural models, graphs, and tables, which are clear and free of misleading scaling. For example, the study uses electron density maps to show the structures of histone modifications and bar graphs to compare transcription factor binding.
  • Confirmation: The structural findings are confirmed using biochemical assays and functional studies, which validate the proposed mechanisms of epigenetic regulation.

docs.title: General Observations:
docs.text:

  • The findings highlight the importance of histone acetylation and deacetylation in regulating gene expression and suggest potential therapeutic targets for diseases linked to epigenetic dysregulation.
  • The results have significant implications for understanding the molecular basis of epigenetic regulation and developing therapies for cancer and other diseases.

1. Experimental Purpose:
docs.text:
• Scientific Question: The study aims to understand how the gut microbiota regulates host lipid metabolism and how dysbiosis (imbalance in the microbiota) contributes to metabolic disorders such as obesity and diabetes. Specifically, the study investigates the role of Nfil3, Hdac3, and Snhg9 in mediating the effects of the microbiota on lipid metabolism.
  • Experimental Design: The study uses germ-free (GF) mice and conventional (CV) mice to identify key genes regulated by the microbiota. The researchers then use gene knockout models and bacterial gavage to study the functional roles of these genes and specific bacterial strains in lipid metabolism.

docs.text:

  • Why This System?: Mice are appropriate for this study because their gut microbiota and lipid metabolism are well-characterized, and they allow for precise genetic manipulation. The use of GF mice is particularly relevant because it enables researchers to study the effects of specific bacterial strains on host metabolism.
  • Alternative Model Systems: Other model systems like zebrafish or Drosophila could be used, but they lack the complexity of mammalian lipid metabolism and gut microbiota interactions.

1. Experimental Purpose:
docs.text:
• Scientific Question: The study aims to understand how IL-33, a cytokine produced by PDGFRβ+DPP4+ cells, regulates cold-induced thermogenesis and the formation of beige adipocytes in white adipose tissue (WAT). Specifically, the study investigates whether IL-33 expression is induced by cold exposure and how it contributes to thermogenic remodeling.

The researchers first identify IL-33 as a key player in the process and then investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying its regulation.

docs.text:

The study also uses germ-free (GF) and conventional (CV) mice to study the effects of cold exposure on adipose tissue.
  • Why This System?: Mice are appropriate for this study because they allow for the manipulation of specific cell populations and genes, and their adipose tissue responds to cold exposure in a manner similar to humans.   • Alternative Model Systems: Other model systems, such as cell cultures or zebrafish, could be used, but they lack the complexity of in vivo adipose tissue remodeling and the interaction between different cell types.
  • Ethical Considerations: Using mice requires ethical approval, especially when dealing with cold exposure and gene editing. The study likely adheres to ethical guidelines for animal research.

docs.text:

    • Histology: To visualize beige adipocyte formation in adipose tissue.
    • CRISPR/Cas9: To knock out CREB, a transcription factor that regulates IL-33 expression.
    • Chromatin Immunoprecipitation (ChIP): To study the binding of CREB to the IL-33 promoter.
  • Why These Methods?: RNA-seq was chosen to identify genes regulated by cold exposure, while flow cytometry and histology were used to study the cellular and tissue-level effects of IL-33. CRISPR/Cas9 and ChIP assays were used to investigate the molecular mechanisms of IL-33 regulation.

docs.title: 4. Group Setting:

    • PDGFRβ+DPP4+ cells vs. PDGFRβ+DPP4- cells: To identify the source of IL-33 in iWAT.

  • Statistical Tests: The study uses statistical methods (e.g., t-tests, ANOVA) to compare gene expression, cell populations, and transcription factor binding between groups. Differential expression analysis is performed to identify key genes regulated by cold exposure and IL-33.
  • Data Presentation: Results are presented using graphs, tables, and histological images, which are clear and free of misleading scaling. For example, the study uses volcano plots to show differentially expressed genes and bar graphs to compare IL-33 expression levels.
  • Confirmation: The findings are confirmed using gene knockout models (e.g., CREB knockout) and functional assays (e.g., ChIP assays), which validate the role of IL-33 and CREB in cold-induced thermogenesis.

docs.title: S1.W2.2. Experimental design II
docs.text:
• Accuracy: 测得真实、正确数据的能力, 对应Systematic error
  • Precision: 良好的可重复性 (Reproducibility), 对应Random error
  • Sensitivity: TP / (TP + FN)
  • Specificity: TN / (TN + FP)
  • Power of a hypothesis test: the probability that the test correctly rejects the null hypothesis (H0)
  • Type I error: "false positive", 指当原假设（H0​）实际上是正确的，但我们却错误地拒绝了; 犯第一类错误的概率即为α (自己设的significance level)
  • Type II error: "false negative", 指原假设（H0​）实际上是错误的，但我们却没有拒绝, 犯第二类错误的概率即为β, 1-β就是Power
  • Effect size: a number measuring the strength of the relationship between two variables in a population, or a sample-based estimate of that quantity. Its significance depends of the sample size
  • Internal Standard（内标）是一种分析化学技术，常用于定量分析。它是指在样品中加入一个已知浓度的化合物（内标物），这个化合物与目标分析物在化学性质上相似，但在样品中并不存在，也可以与目标分析物分离开来。通过比较目标分析物和内标物的峰面积或高度，并结合内标物质的已知浓度，就可以计算出被分析物的含量，这可以提高分析结果的精确性和准确性，特别是在样品的处理和测量过程中可能导致的损失和变化。
  • Significant Figures（有效数字）是指一个数值中能表示其精确性的数字位数。有效数字包括所有已知的数字及最后一个不确定的数字。它关系到测量结果的精确性和不确定性。例如，在数值 0.00456中，有效数字为3（4、5和6），而在数值 100.0中，有效数字为4（1、0、0和小数点后的一位0）。

docs.title: S1.W3.1. Experimental design III: Experimental bias
docs.text:
• Bias: 所有造成Systematic error的因素
    • Survivorship Bias (e.g.)
    • Sampling/Ascertainment/Selection bias：选取样本的方式不恰当
    • Experimenter bias：实验者受自身期望、偏好等主观因素影响
    • Reporting Bias：选择性报告或不客观描述解释
    • Biased Model Systems：模型自身局限、不合理假设或数据输入偏差等
    • Publication Bias：学术期刊倾向于发表显著结果研究，导致已发表研究不能全面反映领域真实情况而产生的偏差。
  • 如何设计unbiased的实验？可以参考课件例子

docs.title: S1.W5.1. Experimental design IV: Types
docs.text:
• Completely randomised design: 将实验对象完全随机地分配到不同处理组
  • Randomised complete block design: 将实验对象按性质相同或相近分为若干区组，再将每个区组内的对象随机分配到不同处理组
  • Split-plot design: 将实验单元分为主区和副区，分别安排不同处理因素
  • Randomised Control Trial: 将研究对象随机分配到干预组和对照组，以评估干预措施效果
    • Placebo: 一种中立的控制干预，但可以与积极效果（安慰剂效应）相关联。
    • Nocebo: 一种负面的控制干预，受试者会经历负面影响
    • Hawthorne effect: 实验对象的行为会随着被观察而改变
    • Demand characteristics: 由受试者猜测研究目的并采取相应行动而产生的效应
    • ‘Screw-you’ effect: 实验对象的行为可能会破坏实验者的目的
  • Cohort Studies
    • Retrospective (回顾性): 通过回顾过去的暴露和疾病发生情况，分析暴露因素与疾病关系
    • Prospective (前瞻性): 从现在开始追踪观察不同暴露组的研究对象，以确定疾病发生情况及与暴露因素关系
  • Cross-Over design: 让研究对象在不同时期先后接受不同处理，以比较不同处理效果
  • Cross-sectional: 在某一特定时间点对研究对象的特征和疾病状况进行调查
  • Longitudinal: 对同一组研究对象在较长时间内进行跟踪，观察其变化
  • Meta-analyses: 综合多个同类研究结果，进行定量分析以得出更具普遍性结论
  • Multi-batch analyses: 对多个批次的数据进行分析，以考虑批次效应并获得更可靠结果

docs.title: S1.W7.1. Experimental design V: interpolation/extrapolation and mixed effects models
docs.text:
• Interpolation: Constructing new data points within the range of known data
  • Extrapolation: Applying your model to calculate values outside of the range of observed data sample
  • Mixed effects models: 统计模型，同时包含固定效应和随机效应，用于分析具有层次结构或聚类结构的数据，能在考虑个体差异等随机因素的同时，研究固定因素对响应变量的影响
  • Random effects model: 将个体或群体的效应视为随机变量，强调从总体中抽取的样本所具有的随机性，更适合于研究个体或群体间的差异及变化，以及总体特征。
  • Nested design: 一种实验设计方法，指的是一个因子（如细胞）被包含或嵌套在另一个因子（如胰腺）中，且不同组的嵌套对象彼此独立，不能跨组比较。主要作用：用来区分不同来源的变异，比如区分基因型的差异、胰腺之间的差异、以及细胞之间的差异。

1. Translatorner: A Transformer-based Model for mRNA Translation
Experimental Purpose:
docs.text:
• Scientific Question: The study aims to understand the regulation of mRNA translation and its impact on protein abundance, which is crucial for understanding disease mechanisms. The central dogma of biology (DNA → RNA → Protein) is well-known, but the correlation between mRNA and protein levels is not perfect (0.39 to 0.79). The study seeks to model how mRNA translation is regulated and how this regulation affects protein levels.
  • Experimental Design: The study uses a Transformer-based deep learning model (Translatorner) to predict ribosome profiling (translatome) from RNA-seq data and gene sequences. The model is trained on human data and tested on both human and mouse datasets to evaluate its ability to generalize across species.

docs.title: Model System:
docs.text:
• Model System: The study uses human and mouse genomic data. These systems are appropriate because they are well-studied, and the conservation of regulatory mechanisms between humans and mice allows for cross-species validation.
  • Alternative Model Systems: Other model systems like yeast or zebrafish could be used, but they may lack the complexity and relevance to human diseases. However, they are cheaper and easier to manipulate.
  • Ethical Considerations: Using human genomic data requires ethical approval, especially when dealing with patient data. The study likely adheres to ethical guidelines for genomic research.

docs.title: Measurement Approach:
docs.text:
• Techniques: The study uses ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) and RNA-seq data. These are quantitative techniques that measure translation efficiency and mRNA abundance, respectively.
  • Method Choice: Deep learning models (Transformers) were chosen because they can capture long-range dependencies in sequences, which is crucial for understanding translation regulation.
  • Technical Replicates: The study likely uses multiple replicates to ensure robustness, though the exact number is not specified.
  • Potential Biases: Biases could arise from data normalization or sequencing depth. These are minimized by using standardized protocols and cross-validation.

docs.title: Group Setting:
docs.text:
• Experimental Groups: The model is trained on human data and tested on both human and mouse data. The groups are defined by cell types (e.g., epithelial cells, brain cells).
  • Negative Controls: The study compares Translatorner with state-of-the-art models (e.g., Riboformer) to ensure that the improvements are not due to overfitting.
  • Biological Replicates: The study uses multiple datasets (e.g., K562, epithelial cells) to ensure generalizability.
  • Modified Group Design: A dose-response experiment could be added to study how varying levels of mRNA affect translation efficiency.

docs.title: Data Analysis & Presentation:
docs.text:
• Data Processing: Raw data from Ribo-seq and RNA-seq are processed using deep learning models. The data are quantitative, and the model outputs are compared with experimental data.
  • Statistical Tests: The study uses Pearson correlation coefficients (PCC) to compare predicted and observed ribosome profiling data.
  • Data Presentation: Results are presented using scatter plots and enrichment plots, which are clear and free of misleading scaling.
  • Confirmation: The model's predictions are validated using cross-species data and in silico mutagenesis, which confirms the robustness of the results.
